large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Goldilocks and the Three Bears

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, discuss fairy tales, and introduce vocabulary (porridge, medium).
Begin Story Time by introducing the guiding question: What is one thing Goldilocks does in the story?
Read for enjoyment and understanding of relative sizes.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects; Compare and order up to 5 objects by a measurable attribute.
Take another perspective.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Tell or retell stories.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Distinguish between letters, words, and pictures.
Share and repeat the details in a text.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to describe the relative sizes of chairs, bowls, and beds as shown in three sets of Activity Cards.
Help children order each set of cards by size.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What stories do we like to tell?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What book did you choose? Is it bigger than the book we read today?
Can you pretend to be the great big father bear? How tall are you?
How is Mama Bear different from Baby Bear? Can you show me?
Can you write about your favorite animal? Is it shorter or taller than papa bear?
Can you draw your favorite scene from the story of Goldilocks? What colors will you use?
Can you make a big letter? Can you make a little letter?
Build something short! Now, build something tall.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Goldilocks and the Three Bears

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder take another perspective and introduce vocabulary (familiar, unfamiliar).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Goldilocks and the Three Bears .
Read closely to consider characters’ feelings and perspectives and review patterns.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns.
Compare and order up to 5 objects by a measurable attribute; Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects.
Take another perspective.
Share ideas and feelings; Tell or retell stories.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Share and repeat the details in a text.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to use their hand to compare the sizes of objects.
Help children create a pattern of too long, too short, and “just right” objects.
Discuss perspective.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What stories do we like to tell?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Show a character in your story who is feeling sad or happy.
Can you act surprised?
How many chairs did Goldilocks sit in before she found one that was just right? Can you show me?
Draw a face. Write how that person feels.
Draw a picture of Baby Bear. How can you show that he is little?
What sound is at the beginning of the word bear? Can you write that letter?
Can you build a safe place for Goldilocks to hide from the bears?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Goldilocks and the Three Bears by Valeri Gorbachev. Copyright © 2001 by Valeri Gorbachev. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with NorthSouth Books, Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Goldilocks and the Three Bears

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share a patterns strategy, play a pattern game, and introduce vocabulary (small, large).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Goldilocks and the Three Bears and asking the guiding question, What do the bears do when they come home?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review patterns and measurement.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns.
Compare and order up to 5 objects by a measurable attribute.
Take another perspective.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Understand and use a growing number of opposites.
Share and repeat the details in a text.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Pattern Blocks to model size-related patterns.
Ask children to describe and copy the patterns.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What stories do we like to tell?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What is your favorite book in our library? Why is it your favorite?
Can you find the largest tool in the kitchen? Can you find the smallest?
Can you make something small using Connecting Cubes? Can you make it larger?
Name your favorite animals in order from largest to smallest.
Can you use blocks to make a large, small, large, small pattern? Why did you start with that block?
Write your favorite letter. Can you write it larger?
How can you build steps? Which step will be the smallest?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Goldilocks and the Three Bears by Valeri Gorbachev. Copyright © 2001 by Valeri Gorbachev. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with NorthSouth Books, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: The Voice in Rabbit’s House

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Goldilocks and the Three Bears

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to review fairy tales, play a measurement game, and introduce vocabulary (leopard, rhinoceros).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts The Voice in Rabbit’s House and Goldilocks and the Three Bears.
Read interactively and connect to relative sizes.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects; Compare and order up to 5 objects by a measurable attribute.
Take another perspective.
Share ideas and feelings; Tell or retell stories.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Share and repeat the details in a text.
Distinguish between letters, words, and pictures.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children compare the sizes of characters in the story.
Have children use Connecting Cubes to build houses to suit each character’s size.
Discuss perspective.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What stories do we like to tell?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Name a story that you would enjoy hearing more than once.
Pretend to be your favorite animal.
How many different animals can you find in the story?
Draw and name one animal from the story you would like as a pet.
Can you make one animal from the story? What materials will you use?
What sound is at the beginning of rabbit? Can you draw it?
What does Rabbit’s house look like? Can you build it?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Goldilocks and the Three Bears by Valeri Gorbachev. Copyright © 2001 by Valeri Gorbachev. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with NorthSouth Books, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Goldilocks and the Three Bears

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, play a capacity game, and introduce vocabulary (empty, full).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, If the bears invited you into their home, what would you do there?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on measurement.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Measure, describe, and compare capacity or how much can be placed inside an object using units and words like “empty” and “full.”

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Take another perspective.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Share and repeat the details in a text.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Share ideas and feelings.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What is your favorite part of this week’s story?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s responses to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What stories do we like to tell?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What book will you read next?
Can you pretend to be one of the bears? Show how you feel when you see Goldilocks.
Do you think real bears eat porridge? What do you think real bears eat?
Can you write about how Goldilocks felt when she saw the three bears?
Make a picture of your favorite character from the story.
Trace the word baby with your finger.
What do you think Goldilocks’s home looks like? Can you build it?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Recognize and create patterns.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Recognize and create patterns.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Recognize how much can be placed within an object.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
